summary_points: 1. MarketAxess Holdings Inc. appointed Dean Berry as Group Chief Operating Officer and Chief Executive Officer, EMEA & APAC, effective in Q4 2025.

2.  Berry's total compensation package includes a GBP £560,000 annual base salary, a GBP £840,000 target year-end cash incentive for 2026, and a GBP £1.8 million target grant date value of year-end equity award for 2026, along with a GBP £2.063 million lost opportunity award.
3. Berry's contract includes non-compete and non-solicitation covenants lasting 12 months post-employment.
1. On May 15, 2025, Vistra Corp. entered into an agreement to acquire seven natural gas generation facilities with a total capacity of approximately 2,600 MW for $1.9 billion.
2. The acquisition is expected to increase Vistra's Ongoing Operations AFCFbG1 per share in the first year after closing (May 2026).

3. The transaction's completion is contingent upon customary closing conditions, including regulatory approvals from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Department of Justice, and is projected to close in late 2025 or early 2026.

1. At ON Semiconductor Corporation's May 15, 2025 annual meeting, shareholders elected eight directors for one-year terms and approved an advisory resolution on executive compensation and the ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor for the year ending December 31, 2025.

2.  Shareholder votes against the election of directors ranged from a low of 1.02% (Hassane El-Khoury) to a high of 8.78% (Paul A. Mascarenas), while votes against the advisory compensation resolution reached 14.3%.
3.  The filing does not specify any future impacts or risks based on these voting outcomes.
1. IDEX Corporation's CFO, Abhishek Khandelwal, resigned on May 19, 2025, effective May 30, 2025, to pursue another opportunity.
2. Akhil Mahendra was appointed as interim CFO, effective May 30, 2025, and received a $500,000 restricted stock award.
3.  The company has engaged an external search firm to find a permanent replacement for the CFO position.
1. Target Corporation's first-quarter 2025 net sales were $23.8 billion, a 2.8% decrease year-over-year.
2.  Despite lower overall sales, Target's digital comparable sales increased by 4.7% in Q1 2025, driven by a 36% increase in same-day delivery.
3.  Target predicts a low-single-digit decline in sales for fiscal year 2025, with GAAP EPS expected to be between $8.00 and $10.00 (Adjusted EPS: $7.00-$9.00).
1. Medtronic plc announced on May 21, 2025, its intention to separate its Diabetes business into a new standalone public company within 18 months, preferably via an IPO and subsequent split-off.
2.  In Q4 FY25, Medtronic reported revenue of $8.9 billion (a 3.9% increase as reported and a 5.4% organic increase) and non-GAAP diluted EPS of $1.62 (an 11% increase).

3. Medtronic anticipates FY26 organic revenue growth of approximately 5%, with projected diluted non-GAAP EPS growth of approximately 4% (excluding potential tariff impacts);  however,  the FY26 diluted non-GAAP EPS range is $5.50 to $5.60, depending on US/China tariff rates.

1. Christina Hennington, Target's Executive Vice President and Chief Strategy and Growth Officer, resigned on May 21, 2025, and will transition to a strategic advisor role until September 7, 2025, at which point she will depart and receive severance and vested long-term incentives.

2. Amy Tu, Target's Executive Vice President and Chief Legal & Compliance Officer, resigned on May 21, 2025, and will depart on June 1, 2025, after a brief transition, receiving severance and vested long-term incentives.
3.  The transition agreements for both Ms. Hennington and Ms. Tu will be filed as exhibits to Target’s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the fiscal quarter ending August 2, 2025.
1. Dollar Tree, Inc. will discuss its first-quarter 2025 financial results (ending May 3, 2025) during an earnings conference call on June 4, 2025.
2.  A press release detailing the Q1 2025 financial results was issued alongside the conference call announcement (Exhibit 99.1).
1. Kenvue Inc. issued $750,000,000 in 4.850% Senior Notes due 2032 on May 20, 2025, through an underwritten public offering, intending to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes.
2.  The offering price was 99.483% of the principal amount plus accrued interest from May 22, 2025.

3.  The Underwriting Agreement contains numerous representations and warranties from Kenvue Inc. regarding its financial position, legal compliance, and business operations as of May 20, 2025,  failure to meet which could lead to termination of the agreement.

1. Republic Services, Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 19, 2025, resulted in the election of all board nominees and approval of executive officer compensation and the appointment of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor.

2.  While approximately 47 million fewer shares would have been voted on proposals two and three if an Arizona statute were deemed enforceable (which it is not currently), the outcomes would have remained unchanged.
3. The company's position on the enforceability of the Arizona statute limiting shareholder voting rights remains undecided as of May 21, 2025.
Failed to analyze filing

1. On May 19, 2025, Richard Allen Grenell was elected to Live Nation Entertainment, Inc.'s Board of Directors, receiving a prorated portion (102 shares) of the annual non-employee director stock grant vesting June 13, 2025.
2.  The filing is an 8-K current report, indicating a significant event requiring immediate disclosure to the SEC.
3. Mr. Grenell's appointment brings decades of experience in diplomacy and negotiations to the board, potentially impacting future company strategy and relations with international markets.
1. On May 19, 2025, Principal Financial Group appointed Joel Pitz as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, succeeding Deanna Strable who became President & CEO in January 2025.
2. Mr. Pitz will receive an annual base salary of $552,500, a target annual incentive of 200% of base salary, and a long-term incentive target of $2,348,125 in restricted stock units.
3. Kristine Pitz, Mr. Pitz's spouse and a long-term company employee, received $225,034 in base salary and bonuses in 2024; her compensation was approved by the Human Resources Committee.

1. Willis Towers Watson PLC held its 2025 Annual General Meeting of Shareholders on May 15, 2025, where all proposals were approved by shareholders representing approximately 91.86% of outstanding shares.
2.  Shareholder votes for the reelection of Paul Reilly as non-executive Chair of the Board received 85,172,746 votes in favor versus 2,712,870 against.
3. Paul Thomas retired from the Willis Towers Watson board, with Paul Reilly succeeding him as non-executive Chair, effective May 15, 2025.
1. On May 20, 2025, DaVita Inc. upsized its private offering of 6.750% Senior Notes due 2033 from $750 million to $1 billion, with the offering expected to close on May 23, 2025.
2.  DaVita intends to use the net proceeds from the note offering to repay outstanding debt, pay related expenses, and for general corporate purposes, including potential stock repurchases.
3. The offering of the 2033 Notes was made only to qualified institutional buyers and certain non-U.S. persons, meaning it was not publicly available.
1. Host Hotels & Resorts, L.P. completed a $500 million public offering of 5.700% Series M senior notes due 2032 on May 20, 2025.
2. The net proceeds from the offering, along with cash on hand, will be used to redeem all outstanding $500 million of Host L.P.’s 4.000% Series E senior notes due 2025.
3.  Host L.P.’s ability to incur further indebtedness is subject to restrictive covenants, including maintaining an EBITDA-to-interest coverage ratio of at least 1.5x.
1. As of April 26, 2025, the company had $15.4 billion remaining authorized for stock repurchases, with no termination date.
2.  In February 2025, the company issued senior notes totaling $5 billion in principal amount.

3. Brazilian authorities have assessed claims against the company's Brazilian subsidiary totaling $138 million (tax evasion), $788 million (interest), and $282 million (penalties), all calculated using an April 26, 2025 exchange rate.
